title: 112_hr718
content: The Act may be cited as the "Huntington's Disease Parity Act of 2011". Huntington's Disease is a progressive neurological condition causing physical and mental deterioration. In the US, 30,000 individuals have the disease, with 200,000 at risk. Symptoms include loss of movement control, cognitive decline, and behavioral issues. Adult-onset typically occurs between ages 30-50. Huntington's Disease can lead to decreased motivation, severe depression, and loss of employment, requiring individuals to rely on Social Security Disability Insurance. Despite medical advancements, the Social Security Administration has not updated its rules for evaluating neurological disabilities since 1985. The Social Security Administration has outdated rules for evaluating Huntington's Disease, leading to delays in benefits under the Medicare program. Individuals with the disease often face incapacitation before reaching the age-eligibility requirement of 65 years. In 2000, the Centers for Medicaid & Medicare Services waived the 24-month waiting period for benefits. The Social Security Administration needs to update its evaluation criteria for Huntington's Disease due to significant incapacitation faced by individuals with the disease. There is a need to remove the 24-month waiting period for Medicare coverage, similar to the exemption for individuals with ALS. Revision of medical and evaluation criteria for disability caused by adult-onset and juvenile Huntington's Disease. The Commissioner of Social Security will update medical and evaluation criteria for disability caused by Adult-Onset and Juvenile Huntington's Disease in consultation with relevant medical organizations. This includes amending sections of the Listing of Impairments to provide criteria for Huntington's Disease. The Commissioner of Social Security will update medical and evaluation criteria for disability caused by Adult-Onset and Juvenile Huntington's Disease by amending sections of the Listing of Impairments. This includes providing criteria for Huntington's Disease in adults and children. The Social Security Act is amended to waive the 24-month waiting period for Medicare coverage for individuals diagnosed with Huntington's Disease. This amendment applies to benefits under title XVIII of the Social Security Act for items and services provided after the enactment of this Act.
